tossups.question: Large values of this quantity for organic substituents results in steric hindrance of molecules. This quantity does not change significantly between second row and third row transition metals, which is caused by the poor shielding ability of electrons in the 4f orbital. Because of interelectronic repulsion, this quantity increases when an atom is (*) ionized. This magnitude of this quantity is similar to that of the angstrom. This quantity decreases across a period due to an increase in the attractive force between the nucleus and electrons. For ten points, name this quantity that represents the distance from the nucleus of an atom to its outermost shell.
tossups.answer: atomic radius [accept ionic radius; accept particle size or particle volume before “second row” is read]

tossups.question: This artist heavily incorporated pink hues into his paintings in one period of his life, during which he painted Acrobat and Young Harlequin. This artist painted a candle that emits red, yellow, and green light in a depiction of the suicide of his friend Carles Casagemas, which led to a three-year period of monochromatic cool-colored paintings. This artist pioneered one movement in an (*) African-inspired work that depicts five nude women posing in a brothel. In another painting, this artist depicted a screaming horse and bull, made in protest to the German bombing of a Basque town. For ten points, name this Cubist Spanish artist of Les Demoiselles d'Avignon and Guernica.

This poet asked “What merchant's ships have my sighs drowned?” in a poem that opens with the line “For God's sake hold your tongue, and let me love.” This author described a creature that “sucked me first, and now sucks thee.” This author of “The Canonization” and “The (*) Flea” addressed one poem to someone whose “firmness makes my circle just,” and in another poem wrote about a being that is “slave to fate, chance, kings, and desperate men.” For ten points, name this Metaphysical poet of “A Valediction: Forbidding Mourning” who included “Death, be not proud” in his Holy Sonnets.

This man’s daughter Laodamia had a child named Sarpedon with Zeus, but was killed by Artemis. The seer Polyeidos helped this man accomplish his most famous feat by telling him to sleep in a temple and go to the well of Pirene. The gods sent a gadfly to stop this man after his hubris pushed him to reach (*) Mount Olympus, causing him to be blinded after falling into a thorn bush. This man used a lump of lead to kill a part lion, part snake, part goat monster while riding a steed that was born after the death of Medusa. For ten points, name this ancient Greek hero who killed the Chimera and tamed the flying horse Pegasus.

A riot in this city began after Proposition 14 overturned the Rumford Fair Housing Act. This city’s police captain William H. Parker compared rioters to “monkeys in the zoo” during a major upheaval that began after the arrest of Marquette Frye. Under this city’s first black mayor Tom Bradley, its police were caught on camera beating a man who was seen pleading (*) “can’t we all just get along?” In this city, police attacked Latino youths wearing the namesake clothing in the Zoot Suit Riots. For ten points, name this city, where the Watts and Rodney King Riots inspired movies in its neighborhood of Hollywood.

One thinker writing in this language posited the “floating man” thought experiment to argue for the existence of the soul. A set of commentaries on works by Aristotle written in this language helped revive European interest in Greek philosophy. A text in this language supporting the Asharite school of thought was refuted in the (*) “Incoherence of the Incoherence,” also written in this language. This language was used by al-Ghazali to write “The Incoherence of the Philosophers,” as well as by Averroes, Avicenna, and other Islamic theologians. For ten points, name this language often used by philosophers on a Middle Eastern peninsula.

An equation named for this scientist consists of a term containing the Laplacian and a scalar potential function applied to a specific quantity, which is equal to the energy eigenvalues of that quantity. That equation named for this physicist is often solved using the WKB approximation. This physicist considered a radially symmetric potential to exactly solve for the orbitals of the (*) hydrogen atom. This physicist criticized the Copenhagen interpretation in a thought experiment that demonstrated the existence of two possible quantum states for an animal. For ten points, name this Austrian physicist whose namesake cat is simultaneously dead and alive.

A national park in this state includes a ceremonial structure and astronomical observatory known as the Sun Temple. This state’s namesake Black Canyon is formed by the Gunnison River. The tallest sand dunes in North America are located adjacent to the Sangre de Cristo Range at this state’s (*) Great Sand Dunes National Park. Massive cliff dwellings can be found at Cliff Palace in the southwestern corner of this state at Mesa Verde National Park. “Fourteeners” in this state including Longs Peak can be found in its Rocky Mountain National Park. For ten points, name this state where one can view Pikes Peak from its capital of Denver.

In this work, a man who quotes A Streetcar Named Desire by saying “Flores por los muertos” mocks a brandy-drinking character by calling her a “Mousie” and referencing her hysterical pregnancy. This work features a section called “The Exorcism” which features an argument over the moon's position before a boy is announced to be dead after swerving to not hit a (*) porcupine. The primary characters of this play have an imaginary son and play games such as Hump the Hostess and Get the Guests with the biology professor Nick and his wife Honey. For 10 points, name this play about the frayed marriage of George and Martha, a play by Edward Albee.

A commander from this country handed Napoleon his first defeat since the Egyptian campaign at the battle of Aspern-Essling. The War of the Fifth Coalition ended when this country signed the Treaty of Schonbrunn following defeat at the Battle of Wagram. After the Battle of Austerlitz, this empire’s (*) Francis I signed the Treaty of Pressburg dissolving the Holy Roman Empire. A diplomat from this country engineered the “Concert of Europe” during a convention to organize post-Napoleonic Europe. Klemens von Metternich was a foreign minister for, for ten points, what country that hosted the Congress of Vienna?
tossups.answer: Austrian Empire [do not accept or prompt on “Holy Roman Empire”]

tossups.question: One of the developers of this game has his nickname “Dinnerbone” rendered upside down. The materials needed to cure certain characters can be found in igloos in this game. Different types of effects can result from consuming suspicious stew, which can be found in shipwrecks in this game. This game includes events known as (*) raids, in which pillagers attack villages. Netherite recently replaced diamond as the most powerful material for making tools, weapons, and armor in this game. Mobs in this game include zombies and creepers. For ten points, name this sandbox game developed by Mojang that has blocky animation.

This leader was aided by Harpagus in their effort to overthrow his grandfather Astyages. Nabonidus was forced to abdicate after this ruler won the Battle of Opis against the Babylonians. One account of this ruler’s death says they were killed in battle against the Massagatea people led by Queen Tomyris. The oldest known declaration of human rights is this leader’s namesake (*) “cylinder." This father of Cambyses II established his capital at Pasargadae after uniting the lands of the Median, Babylonian, and Lydian Empires. For ten points, name this “great” Persian king who established the Achaemenid Empire.
tossups.answer: Cyrus the Great [or Cyrus II, or Cyrus the Elder, prompt on Cyrus]

tossups.question: The Schwartzian transform can be implemented in order to improve the efficiency of accomplishing this task. Franceschini's method is another way of accomplishing this task with a runtime of big-O of n log n. This task is accomplished by processing individual digits in a method called its “radix” type. C.A.R Hoare invented a method of accomplishing this task with a (*) “pivot” element; that method is its “quick” type. Other methods of accomplishing this task with a runtime of big-O of n-squared include its bubble, selection, and insertion types. For ten points, identify this task of rearranging the elements of an array or list into a desired order.

This composer’s Opus 39, Number 6 in A minor opens with rapid chromatic octave runs at the bottom of the keyboard. That étude is nicknamed “Little Red Riding Hood” and is part of this composer’s Études-Tableaux [ay-tudes ta-BLOH]. This composer used three fortissimo A, G-sharp, and C-sharp chords to open their (*) Prelude in C-sharp minor. After being treated for depression by Nikolai Dahl, this composer wrote the second of his four piano concertos. In another work, this composer unusually placed the first variation before the main theme of another composer’s 24th caprice. For ten points, name this Russian composer of Rhapsody on a Theme of Paganini.

In one work from this country, Beatriz’s cousin recites a fictional poem called “The Earth.” Another work from this country features cellmates Molina and Valentin who discuss film plots and form an intimate relationship. Other works from this country where Kiss of the Spider Woman is set include a story set in the poet Carlos Danieri’s cellar, which houses a single (*) point in space that contains all other points. An author from this country wrote about an infinite series of hexagonal rooms that contain every possible book in “The Library of Babel” as well as “The Aleph.” For ten points, name this home country of Manuel Puig and Jorge Luis Borges.

One type of this foodstuff used in Orthodox Christian services is called the prosphora. In Judaism, before consuming meals with this foodstuff, one must pour water over one’s hands three times and recite the “blessing” of this foodstuff, or the haMotzi. A circular version of this food is eaten on Rosh Hashanah to symbolize the Wheel of Fortune. In the only miracle recorded in all four gospels, Jesus feeds the five thousand with two (*) fish and five of these foodstuffs. In Judaism, matzah, an unleavened form of this foodstuff, is eaten during Passover. For ten points, name this foodstuff often baked in loaves, one form of which is challah.
tossups.answer: bread [accept matzah, accept challah, accept lechem, accept loaves of bread]

tossups.question: This country’s first president instituted an ideology of ethnic homogeneity known as the “One-People Principle” and was taken to Hawaii by the CIA after being deposed. An attempted assassination of another leader of this country was conducted at the Blue House in 1968. This country’s first female leader led it from 2013 until her 2017 (*) impeachment. Syngman Rhee led this country during its war with its communist northern neighbor, while Park Chung-hee oversaw its rapid economic growth during his tenure as its military dictator. For ten points, name this country governed from Seoul.
tossups.answer: South Korea [or Republic of Korea; prompt on Korea; do not accept or prompt on “North Korea” or “Democratic People’s Republic of Korea”]

tossups.question: One building of this type in Minneapolis has an exterior primarily made of curved steel sheets that represent a fish and a waterfall and is named for Frederick Weisman. Another building of this type in New York City is shaped like an “inverted ziggurat” and contains a descending spiral ramp that passes through its rooms. A sister building to that building of this type was designed by (*) Frank Gehry and is located in Bilbao, Spain. A “Metropolitan” one of these buildings in New York contains a rooftop sculpture garden and is just a few blocks away from the aforementioned Guggenheim building of this type. For ten points, name these buildings home to art exhibits.

In this play, a character who complains about having to wear a chef’s hat bemoans the lack of true French comedies. A character in this play blames the “Demon of Experiment” for the events that take place in this play. Hats and coats are hung up on a rack in this play in order to summon Madame Pace. Near the end of this play, a girl dies after (*) falling into a fountain, and her brother commits suicide with a revolver. The title characters of this play interrupt a rehearsal of Mixing it Up in, for ten points, what play featuring the Mother, Father, and “Step-Daughter as part of the title group, by Luigi Pirandello.
tossups.answer: Six Characters in Search of an Author [accept Sei personaggi in cerca d’autore]

tossups.question: Cyclization by ER membrane enzymes converts this compound into squalene. Ingestion of this compound by macrophages causes the formation of foam cells. The synthesis of this compound involves reduction of HMG-CoA into mevalonate, the inhibition of which prevents gallstones. To dissolve in water, this molecule is packaged in one of five different (*) lipoproteins. This molecule's primary function is to maintain the fluidity of cell membranes, as well as serving as the precursor for steroid hormones such as testosterone and estrogen. For ten points, name this 4-ringed lipid that can cause atherosclerosis and is transported by HDL and LDL.

Susan Sontag produced a candlelit version of one of this author’s plays during the Siege of Sarajevo. In one play by this author, a black toy dog serves as a stand-in for one character’s surrogate child. A play by this author features a character who produces a monologue that includes delightful phrases such as “quaquaquaqua” and “Acacacacademy of Anthropopopometry.” (*) Nagg and Nell live in trash cans with their son Hamm and servant Clov in one play by this author, while another play features a stage with a lone leafless tree where Lucky and Pozzo walk on. For ten points, name this absurdist Irish playwright of Endgame and Waiting for Godot.

bonuses.leadin: New York lawmakers investigated whether or not the Communist Party paid Abel Meeropol to write this song. For ten points each:
parts: Name this anti-lynching protest song that describes “Southern trees” with “blood on the leaves and blood at the root.”
An early 1939 recording of “Strange Fruit” was made by this singer for Commodore Records. This singer, nicknamed “Lady Day,” also sang “God Bless the Child.”

Like many jazz singers of her time, Billie Holiday got her start singing in nightclubs in this northern Manhattan Neighborhood, which gives its name to a “Renaissance” of Black culture during the 1920s.

bonuses.leadin: In May 2018, this music collective announced a music festival and accompanying album that were both titled Head in the Clouds. For ten points each:
answers_sanitized: XXXTentacion [or Jahseh Dwayne Ricardo Onfroy; prompt on X or XXX or Jah]
parts: Name this collective founded by Sean Miyashiro that primarily features Asian-American and Asian artists. Artists currently associated with this collective include NIKI, Rich Brian, and Keith Ape.
Rich Brian and Keith Ape collaborated with this singer on the song “Gospel.” Other songs by this late rapper include “sad!” and “Moonlight.”
NIKI’s song “move!” was used in a commercial for this company’s watches in 2019. Anna of the North’s song “Dream Girl” featured alongside a hummingbird in an ad promoting this company’s iPad Pro.

bonuses.leadin: A character paid to give lectures on morality in this play is called the “most original moralist” in England by Ezra Wannafeller. For ten points each:
parts: Name this play, in which Colonel Pickering accepts a bet with the phonetics professor Henry Higgins on whether he can reform Eliza Doolittle’s Cockney accent.
Pygmalion is a work by this Irish playwright who wrote about the title woman holding a military rank in the London Salvation Army in his Major Barbara.
Shaw’s Man and Superman features a third act titled for this character “in hell.” Tirso de Molina wrote a account of this literary womanizer.

bonuses.leadin: The theme that inspired this collection was given to its composer by Frederick the Great. For ten points each:
answers_sanitized: The Musical Offering, BWV 1079 [accept either underlined name; accept Das Musikalische Opfer or Musikalisches Opfer]
J. S. Bach [or Johann Sebastian Bach]
parts: Name this collection which contains a palindromic crab canon and Ricercar a 6. The thema regium in C minor that forms the basis of this collection unusually contains a chromatic section starting on a G.

The Ricercar a 6 and Ricercar a 3 from The Musical Offering are both complex examples of this musical form. The two books of The Well-Tempered Clavier each contain twenty-four preludes and twenty-four pieces in this contrapuntal musical form.
The Musical Offering and The Well-Tempered Clavier were composed by this German Baroque composer of The Art of the Fugue.

bonuses.leadin: A novel set in this country features a German explorer’s doomed expedition through the outback, and another features a bet about transporting a glass cathedral from Sydney to Bellingen. For ten points each:
answers_sanitized: Commonwealth of Australia That aforementioned novel about the titular German explorer, Voss, is by this Australian author who wrote about the painter Hurtle Duffield in The Vivisector. ANSWER: Patrick White
Oskar Schindler [accept Schindler’s Ark, accept Schindler’s List]
Julia [accept Julia the Elder, Julia Major, Julia Livilla]
parts: Name this country, where authors such as Thomas Kennealy wrote about Aboriginals in novels like The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith.

Thomas Keneally also wrote a novel titled for this German industralist’s “ark”, in which he saves over a thousand Jews during the Holocaust. Liam Neeson depicted this character in a Steven Spielberg historical drama titled for his List.

The first emperor of Rome, Augustus, exiled his daughter, a woman of this name, to Pandateria because of her adulterous behavior. She shares her name with another woman who, later in the century, was also exiled to Pandateria, twice.

bonuses.leadin: These Romans are crazy! And they sure do love the island of Pandateria. For ten points each, answer some questions about exile to Pandateria in Roman history:
parts: Agrippina the Elder, the daughter of Julia the Elder and mother of the future emperor Caligula, was exiled to Pandateria by this emperor. This second emperor of Rome was named after the river that flowed through the capital.
A later case of exile to Pandateria was that of Flavia Domitilla, who was one of these people. Later examples of these people include Patrick and Francis of Assissi.
Name these types of events where a contract between the male relative of the bride, the bridegroom, and the bride in Islamic tradition.

bonuses.leadin: The Mahr gift is mandatory for one of these events to occur. For ten points each:
parts: Meat that is permissible for consumption at Islamic weddings is referred to by this term, which describes food that has been prepared in accordance with Islamic law.
If the marriage ends in a divorce, this term in Islam describes the period the woman must observe where she must not marry another man.

Name this hypertriploid cell line that was used to develop Jonas Salk’s polio vaccine. The active telomerase present in these cells allows them to bypass the Hayflick limit, allowing for cell division without apoptosis.

bonuses.leadin: Rebecca Skloot wrote a novel about “The Immortal Life of” the woman from whom this cell line was harvested. For ten points each:
answers_sanitized: human papillomavirus [or HPV; do not accept or prompt on “HIV” or “human immunodeficiency virus”]
parts: HeLa cells were taken from Lacks’ cervix, which was affected by a type of this disease. In this disease, which also commonly affects the colon and the ovaries, cells multiply abnormally quickly, leading to the formation of tumors.
This sexually-transmitted virus, whose most common symptom is warts, was likely the cause of the cancer that killed Henrietta Lacks. The vaccine for this most common STD is known as Gardasil.

Alphonse de Courcel represented this country, which controlled great swaths of west and central Africa, at the conference. This country’s New World colonies were less successful, ultimately selling the Louisiana Territory to America in 1800.

bonuses.leadin: Otto von Bismarck’s organization of the Berlin Conference led to the formalization of the Scramble for Africa. For ten points each:
parts: This Belgian monarch used a military force known as the Force Publique to control his holdings in the Congo Free State and used forced labor to harvest and process rubber.

In order to connect British territories in Africa, colonial administrator Cecil Rhodes decided to build a railway connecting Cape Colony to a city in this country. This country came under British occupation during the Urabi Revolt.
Name these conic sections generated by quadratic functions. The standard form for these shapes is often written as “y equals a x-squared plus b x plus c.”

bonuses.leadin: These conic sections have an eccentricity of one. For ten points each:
answers_sanitized: Emma Bovary [accept Madame Bovary, prompt on “Bovary”]
parts: Parabolas are defined as the collection of points equidistant from a point, the focus, and a line, which is known by this term. This line is perpendicular to the parabola’s axis of symmetry and does not intersect with the parabola.

For a parabola whose vertex is the origin, the equation that generates it can be written as “y equals x-squared” scaled by the length of this segment. This chord is defined as the line segment parallel to the directrix through the focus.
Rodolphe breaks up his affair with this character by placing a letter in a basket of apricots. After this character’s death, the townspeople of Yonville praise the pharmacist Homais

bonuses.leadin: For ten points each, answer the following about fruits in European literature:
answers_sanitized: In Search of Lost Time [or À la recherche du temps perdu or Remembrance of Things Past]
women [or girls; accept Girl with a Pearl Earring]
parts: Edmund Dantes refuses grapes offered by his former lover Mercedes in this Alexandre Dumas novel where he takes revenge on Fernand, Danglars, and Villefort for his unjustified imprisonment.

The narrator described viewing scenic apple trees in Swann’s Way, which is the first volume of this seven-volume work where the narrator is reminded of his childhood in Combray after he tastes a tea-soaked madeleine.
Name these subjects of paintings like “La Grande Odalisque,” “Portrait of Madame X,” and “Christina’s World.” One of these people “with a Pearl Earring” titles a Johannes Vermeer painting.

bonuses.leadin: A 1989 poster asks whether these people have to have to be naked in order to get into the Metropolitan Museum of Art. For ten points each:
answers_sanitized: Oscar statuette [accept Oscar award, accept Academy Award]
parts: The 1989 poster was created by this anonymous feminist art collective led by the pseudonymous Frida Kahlo. This group adopted their best-known features after one of its members misspelled this group’s name.

Another Guerilla Girls poster features a middle-aged white man posing as one of these objects. That poster, which critiques the lack of diversity in the film industry, is titled “The Anatomically Correct [one of these awards].”
Name this vector field symbolized B, often contrasted with the electric field. This field is measured in SI units of Teslas.

bonuses.leadin: The amount of this vector quantity resulting from an electric current can be calculated using the Biot-Savart law. For ten points each:
parts: This law, one of Maxwell’s equations, states that the magnetic flux through a closed surface is always zero. As a consequence of this law, magnetic field lines form closed loops in space.

Gauss’s law would be violated by these hypothetical particles, the existence of which would make Maxwell’s equations symmetric. Paul Dirac noted that the existence of these particles is a sufficient condition for the quantization of electric charge.

Name this current world leader who tested positive for COVID-19 in July. Infamous for stating that “no father is ever proud of having a gay son” in a 2013 documentary, this leader’s hateful rhetoric has led many to dub him as the “Trump of the Tropics.”

bonuses.leadin: This leader recently called several fires that broke out in his home country a “lie”. For ten points each:
answers_sanitized: Federative Republic of Brazil [accept República Federativa do Brasil]
Harry “Rabbit” Angstrom [accept either underlined name; prompt on Angstrom]
parts: Bolsonaro is the president of this large Portuguese-speaking South American country. He hails from its most populous city, São Paulo.

In his 2018 election, Bolsonaro defeated Fernando Haddad, the intended running mate of this former president of the Workers’ Party. This man’s involvement in Operation Car Wash led to his ineligibility in the election.
Name this former basketball star and MagiPeeler salesman who is “at rest," “rich," “redux," and “run” in a series of four novels titled for him.

bonuses.leadin: This man’s illegitimate daughter, Annabelle, compares him to Bill Clinton during Thanksgiving. For ten points each:
answers_sanitized: witch [accept Wicked Witch of the West]
parts: The Rabbit series is by this realist American author, who included a trio of bathing suit-clad girls and the store clerk Sammy in his short story “A&P.”

An Updike novel centered on the seductive Darryl Van Horne is titled for these figures of Eastwick. In an L. Frank Baum novel, a wicked of these figures “from the East” is crushed by a house from Kansas which carries Dorothy and her dog Toto.
Name this European royal house whose strategic marriages and inbreeding led to a namesake “jaw”. Maria Theresa was the only female ruler of this House of Austria.

bonuses.leadin: The Pragmatic Sanction of 1713 was an edict issued by a monarch of this royal house. For ten points each:
answers_sanitized: Frederick the Great [or Frederick II of Prussia; or Friedrich II or Friedrich der Grosse; prompt on Frederick or Friedrich; do not accept or prompt on answers involving “Frederick William” or “Friederich Wilhelm”]
parts: Habsburg state chancellor von Kaunitz orchestrated this reversal of alliances between the War of Austrian Succession and the Seven Years’ War. This event was part of the stately quadrille and saw Austria’s abandonment of the Anglo-Austrian Alliance.
The Anglo-Prussian alliance ultimately prevailed after this “great” Prussian king’s victory at the Battle of Leuthen ensured Prussian control of Silesia.

When Jason was attempting to retrieve the golden fleece, the dragon guarding it was put to sleep by this person. After being abandoned by Jason, this woman murdered her children and fled Corinth on a chariot pulled by dragons.

bonuses.leadin: For ten points each, answer some questions about dragons in Greek mythology:
answers_sanitized: Ares [do not accept or prompt on “Mars”]
Samoa [accept Coming of Age in Samoa, prompt on Ta’u before mentioned]
parts: This son of Agenor slew a dragon while searching for his missing sister and used its teeth to spawn the Spartoi.
That dragon was sacred to this god of war, whom Cadmus was forced to serve for eight years as punishment. Cadmus later married Harmonia, this god’s daughter with Aphrodite.

Name this general location, which is examined in a book which describes the taupou system of institutionalized virginity. An author claimed that fewer sexual norms led to a less stressful adolescence for teenagers living on the island of Ta’u in this location.

bonuses.leadin: Derek Freeman criticized a work that studied this location’s “fateful hoaxing” in his work “Unmaking and Making of An Anthropological Myth.” For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Sex and Temperament in Three Primitive Societies
parts: This Columbia University-educated anthropologist wrote Coming of Age in Samoa.

This other Mead work studied the Tchambuli, Mundugumor, and Arapesh tribes. In this work, Mead claimed that Tchambuli men "primped" themselves and women worked without causing any particular problems.
Name these compounds that are formed from the salts of fatty acids through saponification. These compounds function by lowering the surface tension of a liquid.

bonuses.leadin: These compounds can form spherical structures called micelles in water. For ten points each:
answers_sanitized: nonpolar [accept hydrophobic; do not accept or prompt on “polar” or “polarity”]
parts: Surfactant molecules form micelles because their hydrocarbon tails have this property, which occurs when the electronegativity difference between atoms is less than 0.4. Carbon dioxide possesses this property because the dipoles from each C-O bond cancel out.
Saponification involves applying this type of reaction to an ester with a strong base. This type of reaction involves inserting a water molecule to separate two parts of a compound.

Identify this leader who delivered the Gettysburg Address, the sixteenth President of the United States. In an earlier speech, this president argued that “a house divided against itself cannot stand.”

bonuses.leadin: In one oration, this leader stated, “the world will little note, nor long remember what we say here.” For ten points each:
answers_sanitized: inaugural addresses [accept equivalents indicating speeches Lincoln gave during his inauguration]
parts: Lincoln delivered two of these speeches. In the first, he predicted a time when the “mystic chords of memory” are “again touched...by the better angels of our nature,” and in the second, four years later, declared that he would proceed to “bind up the nation’s wounds” with “malice towards none, with charity for all.”
This 1860 Lincoln speech, one of his longest, was delivered at a namesake school in New York. In this speech, Lincoln clarified his opposition to slavery’s westward expansion.
